results.title: The Dummerer
results.creator_credit: Ollie Martin and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Gothic melodrama, which makes dramatic and economical use of empty frames, overlapping sound and striking images to tell its story of a faith healer’s attempt to de-traumatise and restore the speech of a dumb young man. The results are sensational.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ollie Martin and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School

results.title: The Drunkard's reformation
results.creator_credit: D.W. Griffith and American Mutoscope and Biograph Company
results.brief_description: An alcoholic father takes time to reflect when he, accompanied by his child, is confronted with a stage performance preaching the evils of drinking. Cast includes Arthur V. Johnson, Linda Arvidson, Adele DeGarde, Charles Avery, Florence Lawrence, Mack Sennett, Harry Solter. Silent film with English intertitles.

results.title: The Drug problem, what do you think?
results.creator_credit: Eli Hollander, Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Defines a drug as any chemical that alters normal biological functions and suggests that the advertising media promotes drug use. Stimulates discussion that will help students think realistically about the abuse of common drugs and the danger of buying street drugs.

results.title: The Drug bug
results.creator_credit: Horla Stefanesco, Animafilm and World Health Organisation
results.brief_description: An animated film on drug dependence, based on a La Fontaine fable. It shows how “speed” or amphetamines can begin by helping and end by hurting. The story revolves around the fate of a frog who must perform feats of daring to impress his girlfriend.

results.title: The Drover's wife
results.creator_credit: Sue Brooks, AFTRS and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: The Australian myth of Russell Drysdale’s painting “The Drover’s Wife” retold from a different perspective. Based on a short story by Murray Bail. Cast includes Elaine Gay, Jeff Ashby and Martin Vaughan. (Awards: Winner of Rouben Mamoulian Award, Sydney Film Festival 1985)

results.title: The Drover
results.brief_description: The romantic days of droving are recalled in this film which illustrates the day to day life led by the drover on a long and lonely trip in the great Australian outback.

results.title: The Dropout
results.creator_credit: Henwar Rodakiewicz, Irving Jacoby and Affiliated Film Producers
results.brief_description: Shows reasons for many youths leaving school without reaching leaving standard through dramatised typical cases. Causes are complex, including home background, attitude of parents, emphasis on possessions in a commercial society and pressure to achieve independence. Suggests ways in which schools can help by attention to those left behind and discouraged and shows courses emphasising practical subjects and preparation for work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Henwar Rodakiewicz, Irving Jacoby and Affiliated Film Producers

results.title: The Drive home
results.creator_credit: Annette Trevitt, Dennis Tupicoff and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: This 2D hand-drawn animation takes us on a journey through city streets during peak-hour. The distraction of talk-back radio frustrates a lone woman driver when bad reception draws her attention to the road again.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Annette Trevitt, Dennis Tupicoff and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television

results.title: The Dreaming. Series 6
results.brief_description: Series six of “The Dreaming” consists of thirteen of a total of 78 short animations of Aboriginal Dreaming stories that make up the six part series. The support video accompanying series six focuses on cultural maintenance and its role in improving Aboriginal health. This rich and ambitious project was produced by Aboriginal Nations, an independent animation company committed to employing Aboriginal animators. With reference to an intellectual property protocol developed by the company, the stories were sourced from Aboriginal communities, and the permission to tell and animate them was obtained from community elders. The soundtracks utilise the voices of Aboriginal actors and feature original music by Aboriginal composers. A comprehensive teachers guide and supporting videos introducing the Dreaming and offering insights into the storytelling and animation process are also included.
